fields.physical_description: One side of a pair of boots, most likely worn by women from the city of Yarkand (also known as Shache in Chinese) at festive occasions. It is made of leather lined with bright red and green woollen felt appliqué with elaborate floral motifs embroidered or couched in a combination of silk, metal, gold and woollen threads on its upper and its cuff, with a blue-painted hemp layered at the top of the cuff, a front vamp lined with magenta cotton/woollen ends, and edged with chagrin (or shagreen) between its upper and wooden sole and 4cm-high heel which is layered with leather at the bottom.
fields.dimensions: Height: 43 cm, Length: 23 cm, Width: 8.5 cm
fields.materials_techniques: Leather, silk, cotton, wool, wood. Embroidered. Couched.

fields.name: South and South East Asian Collection

fields.history_note:
According to some online sources, Yarkand is an irrigated oasis farmland in the southwestern Uygur Autonomous Region of Xinjiang in Far Western China. It produces cotton, wheat, corn, fruits (especially pomegranates, pears and apricots), and walnuts, with sheep grazing in the highlands. It is made up of several ethnic minorities such as the Kirgizs and the Ozbeks. Their material lives are still closely related to animal husbandry, with their garments, food and dwellings all distinctively feature nomadism. Kirgiz women are known to wear brightly coloured and highly decorated dresses of bright reds and greens and extravagantly embroidered high boots. The Kirgizs like bright red known to signify good luck, prosperity and love, as well as any bright colours such as whites and blues. As clothing is particularly important in the their semi-nomadic lifestyle, among the Kirgiz handicrafts embroidery and knitting are the most noteworthy, resulting in a highly embroidered and brightly-coloured decorative arts that is similarly brightly-coloured and full of vitality.
